text.text:
The assault on the senses that is Chinatown can be pretty overwhelming, making any decisions there so tough that we avoided it altogether for a while. Then one day, with a random spike in our energies, we rolled up our sleeves to tackle the area's eateries.

The whole ordering malarkey was inherently hit or miss but we put the time in, trawled through the tourist ridden streets, and - completely by accident - stumbled upon some real gems. Find your happy place with street snacks, dim sum, hot pots, and more.

tip.text:
Good friend dolls out fried chicken reminiscent of night markets in Taiwan - you know the ones you haven't been to but you'd like to one day, when you're cool, rich and not famous. They've even shipped the oven all the way from the motherland to make sure the chicken's just as crunchy and tender as the real deal.

You can go for crisptastic little nuggets or get the big ol' chicken breast, sliced up and, er, 'flat packed', if you will, to be as large as... your head. Once it's been tossed in three different flours and double fried then it's up to you to cover it in your choice of magical powders (also known as seasonings). Some of them are a little rogue so - as with most unknown powders - go easy on them. We did like the plum though.

text.text: This baby dolls out fried chicken reminiscent of night markets in Taiwan. Grab crisptastic little nuggets or a big ol' chicken breast. Once it's been tossed in three different flours and double fried, then it's up to you to cover it in your choice of magical powders (also known as seasonings). Some of them are a little rogue so - as with most unknown powders - go easy. We did like the plum though.

tip.text:
In this bustly little bakery, you'll find over 80 kinds of Oriental cakes to lay your hands on. It's all self service here so grab a tray, a pair of tongs and help yourself to the good stuff. The char siu (pork buns) are v popular and make a nifty savoury snack, or a great alternative to that lunchtime sarnie. They look a lot like your average brioche roll - topped with the golden and crispy honey crust - but they come filled with succulent and sticky BBQ pork.

Some of the cakes go in a bit heavy on the cream or the kitsch (hello there kitty!). The custard buns though are filled with just the right amount of goo and chew. We were also quite taken with a sesame seed ball - a deep fried pastry filled with red bean paste and coated with sesame seeds. Basically put your trust in buns and balls and you'll do just fine.

text.text: You can lay your hands on over 80 kinds of Oriental cakes in this bustly little bakery. We put away several char siu (pork buns), kinda like a flakier brioche roll, but filled with succulent and sticky BBQ pork. Some of their desserts go in a bit heavy on the cream but the gooey centred custard buns are lush. Basically put your trust in buns and you'll do just fine.

tip.text:
Named after its biggest seller (baozi steamed buns) this joint is a Chinatown fave. Unlike much of the competition, the buns here are made with flour rather than rice, making a dense and soft dough that is wrapped around pork or vegetables. If you're after a quickie, the takeaway counter is where it's at - we usually grab a couple of the fist-sized buns or a selection of their skewers. Choose from pork, beef, fish balls, tripe, or black ear fungus; then watch them bubble away in a spicy broth.

If you've got a little more time and money to spare, the restaurant is worth hitting up too. It's all about the famously numbing Sichuan spice levels - made up of dried chillies, fresh chillies and whole peppercorns. If it all gets a bit too tingly, grab a cold Tsingtao beer and check out the ironic communist decor. Or is it post-ironic? Or even - considering that communism is alive and well in China today - preee-ironic? Whatever tangent you decide to go down, remember Chairman Mao is watching.

text.text: The baozi (buns) here are made with flour rather than rice, making a dense and soft dough that is wrapped around pork, beef or vegetables. We usually head to the takeaway counter and grab a couple of them or a selection of skewers. Choose from pork, beef, fish balls, tripe, potato or black ear fungus; then watch them bubble away in a spicy broth. In minutes they're yours for the taking.

tip.text:
This cute little no frills cafe is a popular Chinatown hangout for the youth (that's us by the way). You can't help but have a soft spot for its pleasing green facade, reasonable prices and generally rough and ready look. And we know those dumplings are made fresh each day 'cause we stood at the window and watched them at it - perhaps for too long.

If you know what's good for you you'll be ordering spicy pork and cabbage pan fried dumplings. Once they've been plonked down in front o' ya (don't expect a smile you old softy) you'll be wanting to dip them in a combination of chilli oil, soy and vinegar. If it's comfort you're after - wontons in broth it is. The chicken broth might be your standard offering but if you're looking for that Chinese childhood nostalgia hit you're onto a winner. There's tea to be had too - classics, greens, floral types (we liked chrysanthemum and honey) and bubble.

text.text: We've got a bit of a soft spot for Jen's Cafe - we especially like to stand at the window watching the dumplings being made. If you know what's good for you you'll be ordering spicy pork and cabbage pan fried dumplings. Once they've been plonked down in front o' ya (don't expect a smile you old softy) dip them in a combination of chilli oil, soy and vinegar. Miam.

tip.text:
What with all the options in Chinatown it can be quite intimidating to feed yourself, and fairly hit and miss too. Luckily this old fave really does what it says on the tin: some legendary dumplings. As soon as you walk in you'll be greeted by the sight of skilled chefs cheffing about in the open kitchen, pinching up little parcels of fun. The big player here is the xiao long bao (or xiu loung bao or whatever you want to call 'em). They're filled with hot broth so either require a bite and slurp technique, or the risky all in one guzzling.

We'll be sticking to the ol' reliable dim sum menu (dose pork buns doe), but if you're feeling intrepid delve into the rest of the menu and all the weird textures that Cantonese cooking has to offer. There's plenty of ups and downs to be had here, including the gelatinous green tea and smoked plum pudding - which looks like lego blocks but tastes much better.

text.text: This old fave really does what it says on the tin: legendary dumplings. As soon as you walk in you'll be greeted by the sight of skilled chefs pinching up little parcels of xiao long bao. They're filled with hot broth so either require a bite and slurp technique, or the risky all in one guzzling. We stick to the ol' reliable dim sum menu here and have a little fun with the various glutinous textures on offer.

tip.text:
This little nugget is on the corner of Gerrard's street (you see what they did there with the name, pretty neat right?). As with many a Chinatown spot, it's a cheap, no frills kinda place. That's not to say there aren't any tablecloths, 'cause there are. The portions here are generous and the dim sum deelish, making it your ideal choice for a hungover lunch.

We would stick to the dim sum menu and order classic winners like scallop dumpings, king prawn dumplings and roast pork wrapped in cheung fun (a steamed rice noodle roll that looks remarkably slug-like but tastes remarkably good). If you're in severe need, the deep fried dough wrapped in cheung fun is a savoury textural treat and carb-hit extraordinaire. When the hangover isn't blowing quite so hard, we've also been known to order the braised chicken feet, tripe in ginger and spring onion, and some token veggies from the main menu.

text.text: This cheap, no-frills spot lays on generous portions and scrummy dim sum. Go for scallop or king prawn dumplings and roast pork wrapped in cheung fun (a steamed rice noodle roll that looks remarkably slug-like but tastes remarkably good). We've also been known to order the braised chicken feet, tripe in ginger and spring onion, and some token veggies from the main menu. Oh and pan fried turnip cake.

tip.text:
The terms 'cheap and cheerful' and 'no frills' spring to mind when pondering Wong Kei. The food is far from Insta friendly, the decor has a vague waiting room feel about it and you can't expect to be adding your waiter on Facebook at the end of the night (we tried). But if you trust your instinct, there's some genuinely good bites to try at some very reasonable prices.

The BBQ meats on rice won our vote, especially the pork belly which we slathered with chilli oil then happily polished off. The noodle soups are worth a mention too. Go for beef brisket, crispy pork or wonton - delicately parcelled bites in tasty broth, with noodles and spring onion. Some of them are off menu though, so think up what kind of soup you want and ask for it with conviction. We went for wontons and crispy pork - that's right, biatch.

text.text: Wong Kei is far from Insta friendly but if you trust your instinct, there's some genuinely good bites to try at some very reasonable prices - like the noodle soups for instance. Go for beef brisket, crispy pork or delicately parcelled wontons. Some of them are off-menu though, so think up what kind of soup you want and ask for it with conviction. We went for wontons and crispy pork, that's right biatch.

tip.text:
The Lotus Garden's exterior is all tarted up to look like a traditional Chinese pagoda, which fits in nicely in these parts. Tempted as you may be to avoid restaurants with such a brash frontage, in this case you'd be missing out on some remarkably good edibles. The big players are BBQ pork and a mighty succulent roast duck. Don't waste your time trying all the duck in Chinatown, Lotus Garden's blows all the others out the water. We chose to skip the octopus with assorted pig organs but went in heavy on the aubergine with shredded pork and spicy sauce. There's also a lush hot pot to be had - lamb belly with dry bean curd stick.

You might find your thirst levels reaching new heights in here (no we don't want to hear your MSG theories thanks). Luckily both Japanese sake and Shao Hsing Chinese wine are available for your swigging pleasure.

text.text: The big players at Lotus Garden are BBQ pork and a mighty succulent roast duck. Don't waste your time trying all the duck in Chinatown, Lotus Garden's blows all the others out the water. And if you get real thirsty? (No we don't want to hear your MSG theories thanks.) Luckily both Japanese sake and Shao Hsing Chinese wine are available for your swigging pleasure.

tip.text:
We're not too sure about the story of Leong's Legend but we can tell you a little something about the flavours here. It's important to note you may not get the warmest welcome; but don't be a diva, just sit down quietly and order strategically. There's plenty of decent stuff on the menu, some Taiwanese pork buns, enjoyably garlicky greens and their xiao long baos - broth-filled dumplings that need to be eaten at the right temperature to avoid the old mouth burn.

The winning dish here is the chicken cooked in Chinese beer, with Sichuan peppercorns, plenty of dried chillies, chives, lotus root, potato, and adorable bundles of noodles tied in knots. It's hella fragrant, tangy from the beer and just the right kinda spicy. It's safe to say we were pretty pleased.

text.text: It's important to note that you may not get the warmest welcome; but don't be a diva, just sit down quietly and order strategically. We caught some serious feels for the chicken cooked in Chinese beer, with Sichuan peppercorns, plenty of dried chillies, chives, lotus root, potato, and adorable bundles of noodles tied in knots. It's hella fragrant, tangy from the beer and just the right kinda spicy. It's safe to say we were pretty pleased.

tip.text:
Shibuya is a café-cum-bakery-cum-bar-cum-sushi joint. Breathe. Decor-wise it's all clean lines, pale wood and calm Japanese feels. You might want to go for warming curries like their ton katsu with a deep fried pork cutlet or the black cod marinated in miso paste. There's also a pretty good sake selection to be drunk neat or mixed into the likes of a sparkling sake cocktail.

When we're about, we only have eyes for the desserts though - we're partial to a matcha roll cake or the impressive looking bingsu. It's basically a huge tower of shaved ice (made of condensed milk) covered in more goodies - like oreos, strawberries and mango. We like ours topped with sweet red beans and matcha which adds a little tang. They even give you an extra little pot of condensed milk, in case you're not sweet enough. Happy days.

text.text: Shibuya is a Japanese café-cum-bakery-cum-bar-cum-sushi joint. Breathe. We only have eyes for the desserts though - like the impressive looking bingsu. It's basically a huge tower of shaved ice (made of condensed milk) covered in more goodies. We like ours topped with sweet red beans and matcha, which adds a nice tang. They even give you an extra little pot of condensed milk, in case you're not sweet enough. Happy days.
